sp.p: Since I can't help it— I ſwear by this White Hand, to perform the Conditions.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: I ſhall put you to it [aſide,] and I promiſe to reward that performance with my Hand and Heart—

sp.speaker: L. G.
sp.p: To doubt your Sincerity now, would be rude—Your Honour is engag'd, and if you value that, or my repoſe, you won't fail—

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.p: I ſhant't— if my Invention don't fail me.

sp.speaker: L. G.
sp.p: His Relation has diſorder'd me ſtrangely, I would not have him ſee it tho' [aſide] I begin to think of Altering my reſolution— I would not willingly Sacrifice my modeſty to my Curioſity.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.p: You need not— Modeſty like true Wit, is beſt ſeen in thoſe that make the leaſt ſhow of it—

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: You can allow then, that freedom and gaiety are not inconſiſtent with Virtue —that a Woman may give a looſe to her humour, without forfeiting her Reputation.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.p: This and more—I can laugh at thoſe who miſcall Baſhfulneſs, Modeſty— and deſpiſe their formality, who ſhun the mention of thoſe things abroad, they are not aſham'd to Act at home—

sp.speaker: L. G.
sp.p: Such are the Hypocrites of our Sex, who rail at all Mankind in publick, yet Love all in Private—Who make their Sanctity a Baw'd to their pleaſures, as cunning Lawyers rail againſt Bribery, to get Clients.

sp.speaker: L. F.
sp.p: Or the better ſort of Quacks decline publick Operations for Chamber Practice.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.p: Not forgeting the Grave Reformers among us, who would Monopolize Lewdneſs—and forbid others reading thoſe wicked Plays they have got by heart.

sp.speaker: L. G.
sp.p: We will wave this Diſcourſe, if you pleaſe, and retire to a diſh of Tea, and the Cards for an hour or two.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: Agreed—

div.head: Scene Changes to Overdon's Lodgings.
div.stage: Squeezum, No-wit, Overdone, at a Table.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: Here Couzen, the Squires good Health—he will make you an Admirable Husband.

sp.speaker: Ov.
sp.p: I don't doubt the Gontleman's good Qualities—

sp.speaker: No-wit.
sp.p: You are pleaſed to jeer one now—

sp.speaker: Ov.
sp.p: Well what want you.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: Madam the Broker is come—

sp.speaker: Ov.
sp.p: Softly huſſy—Whiſper can't you—here this way [riſes] now what have you to ſay?

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: Nothing, but that he is come for your Furniture, he ſwears it ſhan't ſtand a day longer— you have had it long enough for nothing—

sp.speaker: Ov.
sp.p: I muſt appeaſe him— You will pardon me for a Minute Gentlemen—

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: Here's a do with you indeed [riſe both] 'sdeath, was ever any Puppy ſo backward, when he had ſuch Encouragement too— Behave your ſelf as you ſhould, or by Heavens I'll break off the Match—

sp.speaker: No.
sp.p: Nay, but prithee Dear Mr. Squeezum, have a little Patience.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: Patience! you great Calf you—Zounds I have none left—you have quite worn out mine— Plague on you, take your own Courſes for me, and be Damn'd—

sp.speaker: No.
sp.p: Pſhaw, pſhaw—you ſhan't be angry—here's my hand, I'll do what you would have me.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: Go to her then, and get her conſent—I know ſhe Loves you— I won't tell you all I know neither—

sp.speaker: No.
sp.p: Doe's ſhe ifackins— do's the Rogue love me— Nay, nay, you ſhall tell me— Not be free with your Friends? Come let's hear what ſhe ſays— do's ſhe like my perſon, ha? I gad has this Face taken, this Shape, this Leg, this Hair—have they— come confeſs—

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: You are but too happy, that is the truth on't— Firſt ſhe ſays you have a very pretty Wit.

sp.speaker: No.
sp.p: That ſhows her judgment.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: Then ſhe admires the Careleſs ſhake of your Head—the neat Carriage of your Body— the gentile Shamble in your Gate—

sp.speaker: No.
sp.p: Right thus—

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: Next—but here ſhe comes—now ſtrike up briskly to her—ſhe Loves the Lad that's brisk and Gay—

sp.speaker: No.
sp.p: But hates the formal Wooer— ha! old Boy.

sp.speaker: Ov.
sp.p: The impertinence of a City-Viſitant would have detain'd me from you, Sir,— but I thought ev'ry minute an age till ſhe was gone.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: D'you hear that?

sp.speaker: No.
sp.p: Ay, ay, ſhe is ſmitten that's certain— but how could ſhe chooſe— hum, hum,—

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: Tell your mind then— Couz. Mr. Nowit would confer with you about a Buſineſs of moment.

sp.speaker: No.
sp.p: [Getting behind him.] I can't out with it if I were to be hang'd— Prithee ſpeak for me [Gives him Money.]

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: The fear of a Denial deters him from ſpeaking— He would be happy as ſoon as poſſible— What if the Wedding were to morrow?

sp.speaker: Ov.
sp.p: By no means—what would the Town ſay of me, if I ſhould be won ſo caſily—

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: Say— you were a wiſe Woman— One that underſtand your own happyneſs better than to loſe ſo good an Offer, and ſo fine a Perſon, for a mere piece of formality.

sp.speaker: No.
sp.p: [Clapping him on the Shoulders.] God a mercy old Rock, that was a home puſh.

sp.speaker: Ov.
sp.p: But how am I ſure his Love is ſincere?

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: Sincere enough I warrant you for a Husband— Methinks you have but ſmall reaſon to queſtion it, ſince he is willing to give you the laſt proof of his ſincerity—

sp.speaker: No.
sp.p: [Coming from behind him.] Nay, Gad, as your Couzen ſays, Madam, that ought to convince you— Matrimony is the greateſt hazard in Life's Lottery— He that won't ſtick at that will ſtick at nothing.

sp.speaker: Ov.
sp.p: 'Tis too Sudden—

sp.speaker: No.
sp.p: Look ye— what I propoſe by this quick diſpatch is to prevent rumour—and finiſh the intreigue before any body can know I have begun it—

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: A very nice Stratagem.

sp.speaker: Ov.
sp.p: Your perſwaſion and that perſon would excuſe a Woman's frailty—But

sp.speaker: No.
sp.p: Why there it is again now—pſhaw hang but—Women ofiner ſpoil than make their Fortunes, by being over Modeſtly Scrupulous—We Men of Eſtates take a refuſal as an affront, and ſeldom are at the pains to ask twice—Let Younger Brothers Drudge at conſtancy, who muſt live by it, we are above it—

sp.speaker: Ov.
sp.p: The Fool has reaſon, 'tis beſt making ſure of him [aſide,] upon conſideration I reſolve to leave my ſelf to my Couzen's diſpoſal.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: I make over my Right to Mr. No-wit—

sp.speaker: No.
sp.p: Then there's a bargain made—I muſt provide a Parſon and ſome other neceſſaries—I will leave you two together—

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: Fortune be prais'd ſucceſs attends us—He is yours as ſure as—

sp.speaker: Ov.
sp.p: The Thouſand pound is yours— I am thinking how to manage Affairs when we are Married—In the firſt place I do Solemnly Vow and Swear never to leave London—

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: Nor any of its Vices—Item, to bring his Acres hither, and him to a Priſon—

sp.speaker: Ov.
sp.p: Then will I keep my Gallant in Ordinary, beſides two or three hangers on in reſerve—Game without meaſure; run in Debt without meaſure. And after the Laudable Cuſtom of moſt Wives, domineer over my Husband without meaſure— Not to mention many other Neceſſary Priviledges as eſſential to a Woman's Prerogative, as Chocolate and cold Tea, are to her Health—

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: Come leave cheating, and put the glaſs about—alaſs he is departed—

sp.speaker: Ov.
sp.p: He has a Brother or two in my Cloſet—We will retire thither for Conſolation—Let the World believe.

l.hi: Howe're in publick our Nice Sex pretend,
That Drinking does their Modeſty offend,
All hold the Bottle a good private Friend.

div.trailer: The End of the Third Act.

div.head: SCENE. I.

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: WILL when looking well can't move her, looking ill prevail—

Bear your Misfortunes like a Man, and ſcorn her Inconſtancy—If ſhe be falſe, 'tis well you miſt her— You cannot wiſh your Rival a worſe Plague, than ſuch a Wife— But to Whine and ſneak after this rate, as if there were no more Women in the World, is inſufferable— The only way to become matter of ridicule to her, and of Triumph to him.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: No more of your grave Morals—They are to me like Water to a Man in a Fever, only ſerve to make my diſeaſe more violent— all you can ſay ſhall never make me forget ſhe is a baſe perjur'd Woman.

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: A deceitful Flattering Hypocrite—One that has all the Pride, Malice and Affection of her Sex—The very Epitome of Falſhood and Diſſimulation.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.p: Fickler than a Town Gilt.

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: Fonder than a City Wife.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: Lew'd as a Young Widow in her firſt Year.

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: Ugly and impertinent as an old Maid in her Fiftieth—

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: Hold, hold—

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: Nay, there is no ſtopping me when I am once ſet a going—the Larum will run 'till 'tis down—ſhe is more Tawdry and ill-bred than a Country Silly—More imperious and Prodigal than a Termagant Court Lady—And more Peeviſh than a Caſt Miſtreſs—

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: Will you never have done?

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: Yes, yes preſently—She is—

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: Nay then

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: Stay, ſtay—I thought you might have been for an Inventory of your Miſtreſſes good Qualities— Prithee let me go on— I am brimful of Scandal, and if I don't find a vent for it here, ſhall run over where I ſhould not.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: No—Whatever my Rage made me Utter, ſhe is ſtill at my Heart—I wear her Image here, which is never to be effac'd but by Death.

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: Is not that a very pretty Speech for a Youth of thy Inches—Never to be effaced but by Death! ha, ha, ha—Why ev'ry Clown Writes as much to his dear Margery—Thy Loving Friend till Death us do part, Roger—ha, ha, ha,—

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: You are an excellent Friend to make ſport with my Misfortunes, when you ſhould be ſtudying a remedy for 'em—Lay aſide your unſeaſonable Mirth, and tell me what I ſhall do—

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: Do? the beſt thing you ever did in your Life would be to deſpiſe her, as much as ſhe do's you—Fortune and Women always doat upon thoſe that Slight their power.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: No, No, I want Reſolution for this—I Love her to Madneſs—Without her there is no joy on Earth for me—

sp.speaker: To.
sp.p: If you muſt have her then—don't ſtand to parley, but in ſpite of her young Champion's ſeeming Valour, and her own ſtudy'd Averſion— Sieze boldly on your bliſs, ſhe will like you the better for it—Force is never unpleaſing to that Sex, but when it makes an attempt without compaſſing it's end—

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: To thoſe who want ſuch a pretence to gratify their own inclinations, I grant it is not—ſhe was always held nicely Virtuous—

sp.speaker: To.
sp.p: And may be ſtill—That is no obſtruction to you—If there can be a way found to ſecure both her pleaſure and reputation, and ſhe not appear as a party in the deſign, is not ſhe bound to thank you for it?

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: But that way.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.p: Is ready chalkt out to your hand—You ſay ſhe has hitherto giv'n you all the Prooſs of Sincerity, could be expected from a Woman of her Quality—That ſhe has in all other Actions betray'd nothing of this changeable humour—but manag'd all with that prudence, which is not Ordinary in Women of her Years—

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: This I acknowledge—her Words were always ſo juſt to her thoughts, and her behaviour ſo agreeable to both, that I began to hug my ſelf with the opinion of a Miracle—and thought I had met with a Woman deſtitute of her Sex's Frailties—

sp.speaker: To.
sp.p: Very good—then may not this ſudden Alteration be a reach in female Policy—to try your Temper, and ſee how you ſtood affected.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: Probable enough! but the Knight, the handſome Young Knight—

sp.speaker: To.
sp.p: Is a Relation perhaps—or ſuppoſe him a Rival—nay, a favour'd Rival—

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: Favour'd?

sp.speaker: To.
sp.p: I ſay ſuppoſe him ſuch—you have the more reaſon to beſtir your ſelf, and ſet all your Witts on Work to get rid of him—

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: I'll cut his Throat.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.p: Not ſo haſty—it may be done at a much eaſier Rate than Murther—Go to her, and tell her, that in ſpite of her contempt, you are reſolv'd to Love her, Marry her, and Lye with her.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: And be Laught at for a Madman—

sp.speaker: To.
sp.p: If you have not Patience to hear me out, God b'wy.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: I am Silent—

sp.speaker: To.
sp.p: Take a Parſon along with you—Invite your Friends to the Wedding— I will prepare a Conſort of Muſick to give you Joy—Do this, and ſhe muſt of neceſſity commit Matrimony with you, or let the Town think ſhe has done ſomething worſe—which I am ſure won't ſuit her Temper—

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: 'Tis full of hazard, and may as well loſe me as not—therefore you muſt give me leave to try other Methods, and leave this to the laſt pinch of Neceſſity—

sp.speaker: To.
sp.p: As you pleaſe—Buſineſs calls me from you now—that done you may depend upon my aſſictance—

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: [Solus] What an Age of uncertainty do we live in—No Man's hopes are ſo well grounded as to defy a diſappointment—No Friendſhip ſo firm as to be rely'd on.
Oh! Frank, ſuch a Diſaſter—

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.p: Spare your Exclamation—I know your Diſeaſe, and have brought you a Remedy if you have but Courage to apply it—I heard of your Rupture with my Lady—and therefore took the opportunity of Viſiting her, with my Lord Frolickſome, who is in Love with her Siſter, to ſee if there were any way left me to ſerve you—

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: I am oblig'd to you, for your good Intentions—the ſucceſs I fear—

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.p: Was anſwerable to my wiſhes—I was reſolv'd to be aſſur'd whether ſhe had forgot you or no—ſo made Love to her—She indeed ſeem'd to diſlike my Paſſion—but ſtill there was no mention of you—When I ſaw that would not take, I told her plainly you had quite laid aſide all thoughts of her, and were in Love with another—

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: What did you mean by that?

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.p: Mean? by making her Jealous to diſcover ev'ry corner of her Soul, and find where the ſecret Spark lurk'd yet unextinguiſh'd—The Mine ſprung, and ſhe appear'd to be what I thought her, a Lover diſguis'd in Anger—At firſt ſhe ſtarted and Rav'd at your infidelity, till recovering her ſelf, remembring I was by, ſhe ſmooth'd her brow into a Calm Sigh'd, and ſaid ſhe could forget you too—

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: The end of all this?—

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.p: Was that ſhe took it for a Trick, and as ſuch began to Laugh at it, till I promis'd to give her proofs—She is how in the Park, faſten upon the firſt Woman you meet—you will know by her uneaſineſs how ſhe reſents it— If as a Woman loath to loſe you, 'tis but making your Peace at the Price of a diſcovery, and ſave all yet.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: Thou art my good Angel, and I could Worſhip thee for this Advice—

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.p: You have no time to loſe in Words—about it inſtantly—

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: I fly to follow your Directions and be happy—

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.p: And be gull'd—This was a Maſterpiece of Contrivance, to make my Rival a ſtep to my own Happineſs—But if he ſhould clear himſelf, where is my project then—To prevent that he muſt be ſecur'd—here comes one ſhall do it—
So my truſty Agent art thou prepar'd—are the Men and Habits ready as I directed this Morning.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: All Sir—

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.p: And you can clap a Man on the Shoulder in the King's Name with a good Grace—

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: Never fear— I have not fall'n ſo often into the hands of his Blood-hounds for nothing—I can do it with the true Smile of a Serjeant, Laugh in a Man's Face, and cut his Throat—Or like Judas betray with a Kiſs—You have not told me who it is that is thus to be ſham'd into Limbo—

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.p: You know Mr. Truolove.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: Your intimate Friend!

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.p: That is not material, and might have been omitted—yet I am aſham'd to think ſuch a fellow ſhould ſtart at the name of Friendſhip, and I break thro' all its ties unconcern'd [aſide] 'tis for my Intereſt to have him out of the way—I leave it to you to ſee him ſecur'd, and uſe him well.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: Better than you imagine.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.p: Take this as an earneſt of your Reward—A ſmall Portion of what is behind—The buſineſs once done, you may command me and my Fortunes,

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: I am ſorry our Plot was quaſht by this unſeaſonable News—I promis'd my ſelf a great deal of Mirth in it—

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.p: There is nothing in it—My Brother Love another—a common Thing of the Town, one that Doats upon a Fool—'tis impoſſible—falſe as Hell— a Malicious Report, forg'd by ſome envious Friend, and divulg'd by his Wicked Inſtruments— I am ſorry he was not to be found when I ſent—then the falſhood had been ſoon detected.

sp.speaker: L. G.
sp.p: I had it from one of his beſt Friends—

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: His Rival—

sp.speaker: L. G.
sp.p: A Man of Integrity and Honour.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.p: A Lover—conſider that, and think what he dares not do to become Maſter of his Wiſhes—Love you know is blind to all things but the belov'd object— to which he makes his way thro' all obligations of Honour and Gratitude—

sp.speaker: L. G.
sp.p: The proof of his Aſſertion is ſtill to come—if he gives me that, I hope I may believe him—

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: I can't think ſo—Deſpair may force a Man to do what his reaſon when he is compos'd may be aſham'd of— Therefore I would no more build my Faith upon appearance than my honeſty—ſhe that do's either, will be ſure one time or other to ſuffer for her Credulity—

sp.speaker: L. G.
sp.p: What would you have me do.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.p: Hear what he can ſay for himſelf—You are ſenſible that you gave the firſt occaſion for his Crime—

sp.speaker: L. G.
sp.p: Too true

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.p: You ought then to make way for his Vindication—

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: I told you what your Trial would come to—But I was not to be heard— There was that Darling paſſion of the Soul, that Idol of Womankind, miſchief in it—Pray who feels the effects of it now—

sp.speaker: L. G.
sp.p: Add not the remembrance of my follies to my other afflictions—their weight is enough to ſink me—Oh! they gnaw my very Entrails, and rend my Heart into a thouſand pieces—I could—but Oh? Ha! ſee where he comes with the vile Wretch that Robs me of his Heart—I'll make her know.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.p: Fy, Madam, this Paſſion in a Publick place, where there are ſo many eyes upon you is unſeemly, contain our ſelf— and obſerve—

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: There ſhe is now to my cue [aſide] come come no ſtruggling child, I am a common Enemy to all that put out thoſe Colours—

sp.speaker: Ov.
sp.p: So I ſuppoſed—You look indeed like ſome idle ſtrouler that wanted employment—What think you of a Lady's Service— can you play a fan— comb a Shock—Read a play—

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: All, all from the dreſſing Room to the Bed Chamber—there I am in my own Sphear— a very Hercules—Nothing is too hard for me—Difficulties and dangers I deſpiſe—Dare meet thoſe Gyant Monſters, Modeſty and Honour, and ſpite of them reap the Golden Fruit—

sp.speaker: Ov.
sp.p: You promiſe much—

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: Ay, ay, and will perform much—but before I enter into Articles, 'tis but fair I ſhould ſee my Miſtreſs: Nay, nay, away with that cloud— Alaſs Masks are good for nothing in the World—Of little uſe to a good Face, and leſs to a bad one.

sp.speaker: Ov.
sp.p: I can't comprehend that Miſtery— I always thought a bad Face was prudently to be conceal'd.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: Never—a Vizard is a ſort of an invitation to a Feaſt, which raiſes the Curioſity and gives an edeſe to the Appetite—it makes us ſuſpect ſome very extraordinary thing is hid under it—therefore to have all our eagerneſs checkt with a courſe appearance of homely fare, is an intollerable baulk—

sp.speaker: Ov.
sp.p: Say you ſo— then ſuch as mine is, there it is for you—

sp.speaker: L. G.
sp.p: Sickneſs blaſt her—We may venture cloſer and hear what they ſay—

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: Perhaps you will get that by your liſtening, you won't be eaſily rid off— If you can be content to know what you are well, deſiſt and leave them to themſelves—Time will clear the Miſunderſtanding between you—and what you have now ſeen will then prove matter of Diverſion—

sp.speaker: L. G.
sp.p: I muſt be ſatisfy'd tho' it coſts me my Repoſe—

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: So, ſo—ſhe is within hearing, now is my time—well Madam, I am ſo well pleas'd with what I ſee of you, That I would venture any thing to be Maſter of the whole—here's my hand, you ſhall have Chart Blank, and Write your own Conditions—

sp.speaker: Ov.
sp.p: A handſome Man— They ſhall be few— I hate to fetter a Man's Freedom with formalities— A Rover that runs at all, in my Mind, ſhews vigour and greatneſs of Soul— The Woman who would put a reſtraint upon her Lover, will ſoon find an alteration in him; and what if left to his choice might have prov'd his pleaſure, when it becomes his duty, will prove his utter averſion—

sp.speaker: L. G.
sp.p: Impudent Creature! I can hold no longer.

sp.speaker: Eug. and Sab.
sp.p: Stay, and ſee the iſſue of it.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: For heaven's ſake, name 'em quickly— Your Humour is ſo agreeable, and your Perſon ſo lovely, that I am impatient till I come to ſign and ſeal—

sp.speaker: Ov.
sp.p: To deſire you ſhould quit all other Women for me is unreaſonable— What I ask is to ſhare you equally with the reſt—Only if there be ſuch a thing as honourable Love— a hankering after ſome virtuous thing of Quality breeding in your heart— I muſt adviſe you to caſt it from you, as you would a Snake that will certainly ſting you to Death.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: Honourable Love— Ha, ha, ha— You can't think me guilty of ſuch a Folly— What ſigh at a Woman's Feet! to have my Service ſcorn'd, and my conſtancy rewarded with contempt—

sp.speaker: Ov.
sp.p: To bear the burthen of her Expences, and be the property of her Pleaſures— To ſpend your time and fortunes in gratifying her Vanity, and at laſt ſee the Fairy Treaſure you have ſo long been ſeeking after, dropt into ſome Fools lap that ſcarce thinks it worth keeping—

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: This bites— No, no, I love my ſelf a little better than ſo— I can't deny but I have ſeemingly engaged in ſome ſuch thing— but hang't, it was only for the name of an Intrigue, and to trifle away a few ſpare Hours—

sp.speaker: L. G.
sp.p: [Ʋnmasking] Monſter of infidelity, Villain, baſe perjur'd Traytor—

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: Madam—

sp.speaker: L. G.
sp.p: With what Face canſt thou look upon my injuries, and not bluſh at thy own Guilt— View me well, and then, if thy frighted Conſcience will permit thee, call to mind the thouſand Oaths and Proteſtations you made me to be true— Witneſs that Heaven by which you ſo often ſwore, and which will ſurely puniſh thy ingratitude.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: Yours rather— 'Tis a ſtrange thing that you Women muſt be as unconfin'd in your Paſſions as you pleaſe, and we not allow'd the Chriſtian liberty of following your Example— You ſee, Madam, there are thoſe can like this Perſon, however deſpicable 'tis in your Eyes. I can't blame you. Truly, Sir Francis is a pretty Gentleman.

sp.speaker: L. G.
sp.p: Name that no more— I confeſs it all a trick—

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: So may this be for ought I know— It is as hard to know when a Woman ſpeaks truth, as when ſhe wears her own Face.

sp.speaker: L. G.
sp.p: A deſign to ſound you, and try whether you valu'd me enough to reſent the loſs— the Effects of it are viſible, ſince you can leave me for a notoriou • lewd—

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: No incivility I beſeech you— This Lady is at preſent under my Protection— I muſt not hear her affronted.

sp.speaker: Ov.
sp.p: Alas! Poor diſconſolate Virtue— give her leave to rail, Sir, it is the loſing Gameſter's priviledge— Good Lady! She is Husband-ripe— but to my certain knowledge this Gentleman is diſpos'd of.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: 'Tis ev'n ſo, Madam, Here have I fix'd my happineſs unalterably, fix'd it beyond the power of capricious Fortune, and more capricious Woman—

sp.speaker: L. G.
sp.p: And this is your Reſolution?

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: It is— I have ſuffer'd enough for being wiſer than my Neighbours— I muſt needs make my Court to a Woman of Quality, Forſooth— and a Fortune— but what have I got by it?— Only the experience that whoever would raiſe himſelf by Marriage, is condemn'd to a Slavery worſe than theirs that dig in the Mines.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: Your Honour is engaged—

sp.speaker: Ov.
sp.p: Your Quiet is at ſtake.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.p: You have been well us'd, and may again.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: How! My Siſter here too!— Nay then—

sp.speaker: Ov.
sp.p: You have been ill us'd, and may again.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: Youth, Beauty, Virtue, and all that is defirable in a Wife court you to be happy—

sp.speaker: Ov.
sp.p: Pleaſure, Gaiety, Love, Freedom, and whatever elſe makes a Miſtreſs amiable, invite you to more ſubſtantial Joys.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: [Aſide] I muſt work her to a height, tho' ev'ry ſigh goes to my Heart, and each Tear melts me into ſoftneſs— I flew to meet 'em—to revel in the circle of thoſe dear Arms, and reap a thouſand pleaſing ſweets of Love— Fears, Jealouſies, and all the troubleſome attendants of Conſtancy avaunt— Thus I ſhake you off, and will be for ever free, and ever thine.
Come, my Dear,

sp.speaker: No.
sp.p: He took her by the Apron-ſtrings.
To pull her to his beck—

How! my Lady fair, my Bride that is to be, in communication with another Man— By the Lord Harry, I don't like that tho'—I am afraid they are hatching Miſchief which will light upon my Head— It may be I am a predeſtinated Cuckold—

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: What Fool have we here?

sp.speaker: Ov.
sp.p: [Seeing him] His coming in the nick was unlucky, what ſhall I do— If he ſuſpects any thing, I am ruin'd—Dear, dear Hypocriſy, thou kind aſſiſtant of diſtreſſed Damſels bring me off— hum — there's no way but that.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: Why this demur— prithee child let us be going—

sp.speaker: Ov.
sp.p: What do you mean—

sp.speaker: L. G.
sp.p: Ha! Here's a ſudden change— Pray Heaven it prove lucky—

sp.speaker: Ov.
sp.p: I go any where with a ſtranger— ſure you miſtake me, I am more cautious of my fame than that comes to— Beſides, I am now another's, as fine a Gentleman tho' I ſay it—

sp.speaker: No.
sp.p: [Starting out] As my ſelf, tho' I ſay it.

sp.speaker: Ov.
sp.p: O Law! Mr. No-wit— I'll vow you ſtartled me! here's a Man for you— Do but view this finiſh'd piece of Gentility—

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: Of Foppery—

div.stage: No-wit ſtruts about the Stage this while.

sp.speaker: Ov.
sp.p: This compound of Comlineſs and Breeding.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: Of Foolery and Clowniſhneſs.

sp.speaker: Ov.
sp.p: Now judge if I would leave him for you, who are in my Opinion juſt his reverſe, and want all thoſe good Qualities he is Maſter of — I am and will be his, inviolably his.

sp.speaker: No.
sp.p: Ay, ay— Inviolably— mind that Word Inviolably— there muſt be no fingering here, Sir— none at all— ſhe tells you true— ſhe is another's, as fine a Gentlemen as ever peep'd between Scenes— I could be large in his commendations— but they ſay, he who praiſes himſelf lives by bad Neighbours— Ha, ha, he— Well we ſhall be Marry'd to morrow, and a happy Couple we are like to be—

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: Damn'd Puppy—

sp.speaker: No.
sp.p: Phoo— You are angry now— To ſhow you how far I am from reſentment— You ſhall be welcome i'gad to a ſmall Dinner— you and your Friend— But the Lady I can't ſpare you, Sir— ſhe is inviolable, remember inviolable— So bonos nocios Scignior, as the Spaniard ſays—

sp.speaker: L. G:
sp.p: This was a happy turn of Fortune, prithee help me to teize him a little.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: Stay, let us hear what he thinks on't firſt—

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: So— I have at length recover'd my ſurprize— ſure folly has ſome hidden Charms in it, or Women would not be ſo fond of it as they are— for my part, I can't help thinking it a Curſe entail'd on the whole Sex for their firſt Parents Diſobedience— that as ſhe ruin'd Mankind by hearkening to the Serpents cunning— her poſterity might all ruine themſelves by doating on Mankind's fooleries—

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: And thus your Wiſdom has determin'd it— pray, Sir, for which of Adam's ſins was the curſe of Perpetual Diſappointment entail'd upon his Sons?

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: Believing a Woman—

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: Not that I would accuſe your Prudence of a Diſappointment— I know you have fixt your happineſs, unalterably ſixt it— beyond the power of capricious Fortune, or more capricious Woman—

sp.speaker: L. G.
sp.p: That you are juſt now flying to meet Pleaſure, Gaiety, Love and Freedom in the Arms of a kind yielding Miſtreſs—

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: Scoff on— I can bear it all, 'tis what I have deſerved— yet—

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.p: Ay, ay, Brother— poor diſconſolate Virtue, give her leave to talk, ſhe is a loſing Gameſter— You underſtand Phyſiognomy— Is the Lady Husbandripe— How ſtands your Stomach— Will a fine Woman and 3000 l. a Year down with you yet?

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: Do you join to make me wretched too?

sp.speaker: L. G.
sp.p: Don't tempt his virtue, Child— The Gentleman is engaged— you would not have him inconſtant to a Lady that loves him ſo tenderly as ſhe does— I really believe it would break her Heart, if he ſhould leave her—

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: It would kill her— She is certainly a paſſionate Lover— How readily ſhe gave her Hand to another, rather than embroil him in a Quarrel—

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: For Heaven's ſake ſpare me, and forgive my weakneſs— I can Love you ſtill, Love you honourably—

sp.speaker: L. G.
sp.p: Honourably— Ha, ha, ha— What ſigh at a Woman's Feet— To have your ſervices Scorn'd, and your conſtancy rewarded with Contempt— I can't think you guilty of ſuch a Folly— You may now be as free as Air— No reſtraint upon your Humour— Nothing to check your Pleaſures— I would not for the World diſturb you in this happy State—

sp.speaker: Eug. and Sab.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: L. G.
sp.p: What is the matter?

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: We have been taking the Gentleman's Dimenſions, to know what employment he his fit for— I think he had beſt turn Poet—

sp.speaker: L. G.
sp.p: Why ſo?

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: Becauſe he bears a baulk in his hopes ſo heroically— Upon ſecond thoughts the Man may come to preferment— he has a good promiſing Look, and a ſmooth Tongue— What think you of daily Waiter to ſome decay'd Beauty, who will pay well for being flatter'd?—

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.p: Or Nightly retainer to a buxom City Wife, who Marries an old dull Alderman, in order to maintain a ſpruce young Beaux—

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: Very well, Ladies— And thus you have diſpos'd of me— You might have been ſo Civil as to take me into ſervice among your ſelves— What if I were Butler to one of you— there are priviledges belonging to that place— You ſhare my Gains, and I your pleaſures— or a Page— 'tis true I am ſomething of the Eldeſt— yet I can Lye, Flatter, Manage an Intreague, or ſing a brisk ſmart Song, as you call it, with e're a young Rogue of 'em all— Then for performance, my abilities go far beyond theirs.

sp.speaker: L. G.
sp.p: Nay now he grows ſatyrical— we ſhall never ſtand him— we had beſt Capitulate— give him Chart Blanc, and let him Write his own Conditions—

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha—

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: There's no oppoſing three of you— Therefore I leave you all with this hearty Curſe—

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.p: What, your Siſter too!—

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: Ay, ay, you are a Woman— May you doat upon Fools, and be ſlighted— Have all the deſires of Love about you, and be forc'd to live Honeſt, and in ſpite of your own warm Wiſhes be Virtuous out of Neceſſity—

sp.speaker: L. G.
sp.p: In return, may you never be free from Love, yet never meet with any Woman but will leave you for a Fool, as the Lady did juſt now— So Adieu.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: Now let us home, and thank your Stars for this opportunity of crying Quits with him— This looks like a deſign of his to retort your Stratagem upon you again— but ſee what comes of it— Thus it always fadges, when Mankind ſet their Wits againſt ours— We have ever had the better of 'em in cunning ſince the World began, and ſhall till it ends.

l.hi: In Politicks themſelves the Fools may Pride,
But Fortune ſtill is on the Female ſide.

div.trailer: The End of the fourth ACT.

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: 'TIS impoſſible—He can't be ſo great a Villain—

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: You are at your liberty to believe, Sir— But that he intended this, is as true, as that theſe Twenty Pieces were the earneſt of a greater Reward for me to do the Work.

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: Forgive my incredulity— I always took Frank Richley for an honeſt wellmeaning Man— One that would no more do an ill thing to his Friend, than take it from him— Therefore to be ſurpriz'd with this ſudden Change, muſt needs confound me—

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: I was equally amaz'd when he propos'd it, knowing the intimacy that had always been between 'em— and ſhould have told him ſo, had I not ſeen a proſpect of ſerving Mr. True-love by undertaking it—

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: He is happy in your Honeſty— How many Men in the World would have gone through with it, if it were only for the pleaſure of doing an Injury—

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: I ſcorn ſuch a temper— The lowneſs of my Fortunes may make me ſtoop to cozen Knaves and Fools— becauſe to cheat the one, is ſerving them in their own kind; and to put upon the other, but making that uſe of 'em which Nature intended them for— I am ſtill above ev'ry thing that is ungenerous— and now I have loſt all, retain a veneration for Merit, which I am always ready to ſhew upon occaſion—

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: I love your Principles— and thus embrace your Friendſhip—

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: I ſhall ſtudy to deſerve the Honour— You are thoughtful.

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: I was conſidering how to make this diſcovery turn to account— It was luckily thought on— Kind Invention, I thank thee— It is decreed— Treachery ſhall undermine it ſelf, and Policy unravel its own deſigns.

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: Won't you ſee him then?

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: Not 'till I have made his Happineſs compleat— Something is working in this Brain, which if it ſucceeds, will turn that to his advantage, which was meant for his ruin— If it does not, the diſappointment lights here, and goes no farther— You have communicated this to no body elſe?

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: No body at all—

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: Then be it ſtill a Secret— His trouble may work too much upon his Spirits, if he be long alone— Do you make haſte to him, and divert his melancholy Thoughts— I'le follow you in leſs than half an Hour— One word more— Tell him nothing of any Project in hand—

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: I ſhan't— a good Morning, and ſucceſs be with you—

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: [ſolus] Henceforth let no Man think to know another thoroughly— The Art of double-dealing is ſo much reſin'd in our Age, that it can put upon us ev'n in Frienſhip, whoſe Nature is undeſigning and ſimple— It can counterfeit openneſs in its cloſeſt Intrigues, and make thoſe profeſſions of kindneſs ſeem moſt ſincere, which are moſt artificial— So true is that excellent obſervation—

l.hi: No Mask like open Truth to cover Lies,
As to go naked is the beſt diſguiſe.

div.head: SCENE changes to Lady G's Houſe.

sp.speaker: L. G.
sp.p: You have indeed oblig'd me, and I were ingrateful not to thank you for it— But to be thus importunate for a Reward, looks as if your Intereſt were more concern'd in this Diſcovery than mine.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.p: Shrew'dly gueſs'd.

sp.speaker: L. G.
sp.p: A Lover ſhould make all his actions their own reward, and ask no more for the trouble of ſerving a Miſtreſs, than the Pleaſure of having done it—

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.p: But when he is bid to hope, can you blame him for putting you in mind?—

sp.speaker: L. G.
sp.p: Let him do it modeſtly— Too much earneſtneſs looks peremptory, and bears the face of a demand, rather than a Petition— It ſeems to diſtruſt my Honour, and retrench my Bounty, by making that a Debt which I deſign'd a Favour.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.p: I have no ſuch bold thoughts about me.

sp.speaker: L. G.
sp.p: Why do you urge me thus?

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.p: Becauſe I know Anger is now the predominant Paſſion of your Soul, and ſtifles thoſe ſmall remains of Love, which if I ſhould let you cool, might plead for my Rival, and re-inſtate him in your good Graces—

sp.speaker: L. G.
sp.p: The Anſwer is free and ingenious— But ſuppoſe I ſhould, in this heat, conſent to be yours — Don't you dread the reſult of my calmer Hours?—Are you not afraid, that ev'n when you are Maſter of my Perſon, he ſhou'd poſſeſs my Heart?

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.p: Your Honour would ſecure thoſe Fears.

sp.speaker: L. G.
sp.p: Why not my breach of promiſe then?

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.p: There is a wide difference in the Obligation— Virtue won't let a Woman of your prudence diſpenſe with the ſacredneſs of your Marriage-Vows— But ſuch a ſlight thing as a Promiſe never checks your Wiſhes—

sp.speaker: L. G.
sp.p: You will force me to declare, then—

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.p: Not for the World— I know whence my happineſs muſt be deriv'd, and ſhould receive the grant of it with more pleaſure than

l.hi: Wretched Captives do their freedom gain,
Or Ship-wreck'd Saylors ſcape the ſtormy Main.

sp.speaker: L. G.
sp.p: 'Tis hard to forget your Friend with the ſame eaſe he did me— Yet a few days will blot him from my Memory, to make room for a more worthy impreſſion.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.p: I ſhall wait the alteration with impatience— This raſcally Boy will ſpoil all with ſtaying ſo long.

sp.speaker: Footm.
sp.p: Your Man, Sir, deſir'd me to bring you this immediately— 'Tis Buſineſs of vaſt importance, and requires your preſent knowledge.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.p: By your Ladyſhip's leave.

sp.speaker: L. G.
sp.p: He ſeems in great amazement—

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.p: My preſent knowledge indeed— Leave the Town ſo ſuddenly, without giving me longer notice— 'Tis unkind, very unkind— What I ſhould ſcarce have done to Harry True-love.

sp.speaker: L. G.
sp.p: Comes that from him —

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.p: It do's, Madam— He writes, that having abjur'd the whole Female Sex, and with it all the pleaſures of this Town, He reſolves to bury himſelf in a ſilent retreat— His deſire is to ſee me before he goes— I can't deny him; for though I hate his beſeneſs, I ſtill love his Perſon— Your Ladyſhip will pardon me for leaving you ſo abruptly— This or nothing will make her mine.

sp.speaker: L. G.
sp.p: How! go from hence upon ſo ſlight provocation— Why, let him go— But he may never return— What concern is that of mine? He has already forgot me, and I wou'd— but can't forget him— Reaſon tells me, I ought to think no more of him— Love, ſtronger than Reaſon, ſays, I may and ought to think of him— Not only think of him, but ſee him, ſtay him, and make him my own—

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: Your own! What elſe— Here's a ſtir about a Husband indeed— before I'de trouble my ſelf for a Man thus, I think I ſhould—

sp.speaker: L. G.
sp.p: What?

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: Marry him out of hand— 'Tis the only Cure for your Diſeaſe—

sp.speaker: L. G.
sp.p: 'Tis a Cure that genorally proves the greateſt Diſeaſe.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: That's as you chuſe your Phyſician— Take but an able Man, I'le engage for the ſufficiency of the Remedy—

sp.speaker: L. G.
sp.p: You are a bold Diſputant, to argue againſt Experience— I have try'd it, and don't think it ſo Soveraign—

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: Your Lord was old, and paſt practice— There's the Reaſon.

sp.speaker: L. G.
sp.p: You make me bluſh— Yet I ſhou'd take your Counſel, but it is now out of my power.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: The Bleſſing is within reach, if you will be at the pains to lay hold of it—

sp.speaker: L. G.
sp.p: There's you miſtake— You don't know who I have had with me here—

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: Yes, yes, Mr. Richley— I met him at the Door in great haſte— What of him?

sp.speaker: L. G.
sp.p: He receiv'd Advice juſt now, That True-Love is leaving the Town in a pet, with a full reſolution never to ſee it again.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: And you believe he intends it?

sp.speaker: L. G.
sp.p: He is gone by this time.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: Pleaſure has too great a hank upon his Affections, to be ſhook off ſo eaſily— At worſt, if he ſhould be ſo far tranſported, as to venture half a ſcore Miles out of Town— He will ſoon turn back again.

sp.speaker: L. G.
sp.p: Why ſo?

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: Is that a Queſtion to be ask'd of a Man who has liv'd thus long here in full Enjoyment of all that is delightful?— What ſhould one of his Life and Converſation do in the Country, where there is no Park, no Play, no Love, no Raillery; and to ſum up all, no good Wine?

sp.speaker: L. G.
sp.p: But in exchange, there are—

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: Innocent Diverſions you would ſay— Such as your honeſt Clod-pates uſe— Noiſe and Nonſenſe will be very agreeable Entertainments to him! — His Humour will neither ſuit with the brisk dullneſs of the Young, nor the grave Wiſdom of the Old.

sp.speaker: L. G.
sp.p: He that will, may find Men of Senſe every where.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: That is not the thing— A great many are Men of Senſe in their own way, few in his— Youth muſt meet a gay reſemblance of it ſelf, or it will never be pleas'd. Preciſeneſs and Moroſity, tho' accompany'd with Knowledge, muſt be tedious to him— And he'll never endure to hear the Delights of his paſt life rail'd at— After all— Men of his temper, look upon the Country as a ſort of large Forreſt, in which the greateſt Wild Beaſt is a Country Squire.

sp.speaker: L. G.
sp.p: This don't ſatisfie me, I am afraid my Lover is—

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: Very unfortunate in his Friends.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: Whom would you point at, Sir?

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: Not you, Sir, tho' you are his Rival, you never were his Friend, his boſom Friend— the Conſident of all his ſecrets; the Man whom before the whole World he lov'd and truſted.

sp.speaker: L. G.
sp.p: Where will this end?

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: In the deſtruction of a Villain, if I could meet him; but Fate reſerves him for a more ſignal juſtice— Poor unhappy Truc-love!

sp.speaker: L. G.
sp.p: What of him? he is well I hope. No ill accident has prevented his Journey— If it has, ſpeak— Why thus ſilent? Pity my misfortunes, and do not rack me thus with doubts—

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: His journey! For Heaven's ſake what does your Ladyſhip mean, do you mock, or are you ſerious?

sp.speaker: L. G.
sp.p: Serious enough, if you would be ſo: You know nothing of his going into the Countrey this Morning?

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: 'Tis all Myſtery to me, where am I? what do I do? am I awake? perhaps he can fly; if he can't, I am ſure he was juſt now in no capacity to travel.

sp.speaker: L. G.
sp.p: Ha! He is murther'd then; give way to my juſt grief, I muſt, and will ſee him; bind up his Wounds; make theſe Arms his Monument, and if it be poſſible, warm him into life again.

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: I am glad to ſee this concern however. [Aſide.] There is no occaſion for it; he lives, but unwillingly; ſince you can be a party in ruining him: He would have come himſelf to tell you this, if he could.

sp.speaker: L. G.
sp.p: What ſhould hinder him, if he be well and in Town? I am inform'd he is not. Mr. Richley—

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: Dares not abuſe your Belief after this rate. He is too well acquainted with the cauſe of his abſence, to tell you ſo. In ſhort, he is at this very time under an Arreſt for a Sum of Money borrow'd of him: The other is only a blind to deceive you.

sp.speaker: L. G.
sp.p: Now I ſee thro' his diſguiſe, and underſtand the meaning of his officiouſneſs: This was a Stratagem of his, to make my Revenge do what my Love would not. Pitch upon him for a Husband: He ſhall find I can be ſenſible of an Affront: I ſhall have your aſſiſtance, Sir?

sp.speaker: To.
sp.p: Very readily.

sp.speaker: L. G.
sp.p: And yours, Siſter?

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.p: Thro' Fire and Water to puniſh ſuch ingratitude.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.p: Mrs. Eugenia!

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.p: At your ſervice. You ſee in oppoſition to a known Maxim; Sometimes Women can be chang'd into that lordly Creature Man, at leaſt in appearance! We can aſſume maſculine Habits, and maſculine Souls too, to ſerve a turn, and do a little miſchief.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.p: I know one has paid for the Experiment.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: He muſt thank my Siſter for the harm I did him; ſhe was the Contriver, I but the Inſtrument: He knows where to demand ſatisfaction.

sp.speaker: L. G.
sp.p: I'le take care he ſhan't trouble you; what is the Debt?

sp.speaker: To.
sp.p: Five Hundred Pounds—

sp.speaker: L. G.
sp.p: 'Tis hard in this ſcarcity of Money to raiſe ſo much— But he ſhall be bail'd.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.p: I have taken care of that; I can releaſe him from durance: Would I could as eaſily free him from the apprehenſions of loſing you.

sp.speaker: L. G.
sp.p:
Be that my Buſineſs, yours to bring him hither; for ſince we are joint-ſha
• ers in the Injury, we will be ſo in the revenge.

At laſt, I am beyond the danger of a Ship-wrack— There are now no more Rocks or Sands to periſh by; the Harbour is within view, and I juſt going aſhore to enjoy that Wealth my eager hopes thus long have aim'd at; all my care is for you • ow.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: My Voyage is as near an end as yours. One Wedding may chance to ſerve us • oth; I expect my Lord every minute.

sp.speaker: L. G.
sp.p: Why in this dreſs?

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: To teize him a little, I muſt have t'other mad fling, tho' I ben't marry'd this Month for it. How is your buſineſs to be manag'd?

sp.speaker: L. G.
sp.p: As we order'd at firſt: The Gown and other things are not laid away yet; • have thought of ſome ſmall addition to make it more entertaining, which you ſhall • now anon: 'Tis high time I were preparing for him.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: How ſimply will the poor Lover look, when he finds he is caught— I • hink I hear ſome body upon the ſtairs.

sp.speaker: L. G.
sp.p: I'le leave you to your ſelf.

div.stage: Eugenia goes to the Glaſs, takes out a Comb, careens her Wig, and practices ſeveral ridiculous poſtures before it.

sp.speaker: L. F.
sp.p: What have we here, Narciſſus admiring the reflexion of his own Face? He is 〈◊〉 taken up with his dear ſelf, he can mind nothing elſe.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: At firſt addreſs I make my Honour thus— No, that is ſomething too ſtiff— •• en— Not quite low enough— here I mend it— ay, that's pretty well— • ow for my Speech— hum, hum,
sp.stage: takes ſnuſh every word or two.
sp.p: • oſt divine Creature, the brightneſs of your perfections has ſo captivated my daſled • eaſon— By Heav'n! I have forgot my Chin-patch. Oh indecency!

sp.speaker: L. F.
sp.p: There's a good harangue ſpoil'd, for a raſcally Valet's neglect.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: Now all is right; [ſurveys her ſelf] Stay, where did I leave off? Oh! ſo captivates my daſled Reaſon, that ſpite of my ſelf I am become your Slave; yet glory in my Chains.

sp.speaker: L. F.
sp.p: What the Devil is all this?

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: Since they give me opportunity to offer at your feet a Heart, many have in vain ſigh'd for.

sp.speaker: L. F.
sp.p: I wonder he forgot himſelf ſo long.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: The Ladies court, the Men envy me— but for your ſake, Geddemmee, I deſpiſe both, and here reſolve to ſpend the remainder of my days, to let the World know you have Charms to fix inconſtancy it ſelf! You may doubt my Truth: But command, and by yon azure Sky I will do wonders.

sp.speaker: L. F.
sp.p: Sure he won't promiſe her to quarrel; that indeed would be a wonder. [Servant croſſes the Stage.] Pray do me the favour to tell Madam Eugenia, I am here to wait upon her.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: I will, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: [Turns about] I proteſt, Sir, I am very unfortunate, that my more profound Cogitations would not permit me to take cognizance of your Perſon ſooner: Yet, canſaund me, Sir, I am yours as low as the Centre—

sp.speaker: L. F.
sp.p: There's no harm done, Sir, unleſs I diſturb'd your more profound cogitations.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: No, Sir— not diſturb'd; you rais'd me from a pretty amuſement indeed: I would not for the Univerſe, you ſhould think me ſo vain as to make it my Employment. 'Tis neceſſary to ajuſt before we viſit, elſe I never trouble a Glaſs— Will you be pleas'd to uſe it, Sir; it is no Flatt'rer, I can aſſure you.

sp.speaker: L. F.
sp.p: I can ſcarce believe him there, he would not be ſo intimate with it, if it were not—

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: You underſtand faſhion it may be; pray, what is your Opinion of this Suit? view it, view it well; is there not ſomething of Genius viſible in it? 'Tis all French, upon Honour, bought of a French-man, made by a French-Man, and is now—

sp.speaker: L. F.
sp.p: Worn by a damn'd Engliſh Fop— The Farce grows tedious.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: The Pattern all the Beau monde dreſs by. Well, thoſe French are an ingenious contriving People; they ſend us over ſo many pretty Devices and Inventions, ſo many unneceſſary Faſhions in a Year! thoſe unneceſſary Faſhions are a great help to a Kingdom.

sp.speaker: L. F.
sp.p: How ſo?

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: Oh Ged! they encourage Induſtry, and keep thouſands in employment, that would otherwiſe be idle; you ſhall have a Man, now a days, put one Suit to as many uſes as a Welſh Parſon does his thread-bare Caſſock, yet pretend to be genteel. Now 'tis my way to keep a particular Suit for ev'ry occaſion.

sp.speaker: L. F.
sp.p: Inſuſſerable Fop!

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: I have my dancing, viſiting, gaming, and drinking Cloaths; theſe are my fighting Cloaths.

sp.speaker: L. F.
sp.p: So I ſhould have gueſs'd by their freſhneſs.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: Theſe I wear but ſeldom; I was to have met my Lord Frolickſome this Morning upon a Challenge; but he was ſo wiſe as to prefer his ſafety to his Honour.

sp.speaker: L. F.
sp.p: Ha, my Rival! who has plaid me ſo many tricks—Perhaps he had reaſon for it.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: Yes, yes, his Fear is Reaſon ſufficient.

sp.speaker: L. F.
sp.p: He was never held a Coward, ſure ſome more particular obligation hinder'd him.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: A good Jeſt— why, Sir, do you think any obligation particular enough to ſacrifice a Man's Honour to?

sp.speaker: L. F.
sp.p: The Commands of a Miſtreſs would tye my Hands. Can any Man pretend to love, and refuſe to ſacrifice his Honour to his Paſſion?

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: There you poſe me. But between you and I, his Miſtreſs never thinks ſo much of him, as to honour him with her Commands.

sp.speaker: L. F.
sp.p: But between you and I, ſhe does think ſo much of him, and to my knowledge did honour him with this—

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha — I can't but laugh to think on't! She had a deſign to make him ridiculous to the World, and conſulting how to effect it, put him upon this. He, poor Lover, it ſeems has been punctual to his own gulling; and I am here according to aſſignation to laugh at him, and toy away an Hour with her.

sp.speaker: L. F.
sp.p: You are a favourite!

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: You ſeem to be an honeſt fellow, I don't care if I make you my Confident: I have had her a hundred times, but enjoyment has pall'd my appetite— This ſhe I believe perceives by my coldneſs, and has propos'd ſuch a thing as drawing my Lord in for a Marriage— He will ſerve well enough to father ſuch Children as ſhe provides for him.

sp.speaker: L. F.
sp.p: You are miſtaken in him, he will father no Children but of his own getting, for you nor any Fool in England; and ſo he will tell you.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: Why you don't deſign to betray me? Gad's my life, I would not have you tell it abroad; I deſign'd it ſhould be a Secret between us two.

sp.speaker: L. F.
sp.p: Did you ſo? I ſhall cut your Throat for an impudent young Dog.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: Help, help—

sp.speaker: L. F.
sp.p: I would not have you tell it abroad, I deſign'd it ſhould be a Secret between us two.

sp.speaker: L. G.
sp.p: Put your Miſtreſs to the Squeak already! you are a termagant Conquerour I ſee, and give no quarter—

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: Let him do his worſt, I defy him— Here's my Hand, my Lord, I'le meet you Body for Body, in any place you dare name.

sp.speaker: L. F.
sp.p: St. James's Church.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: I as little expected to hear that word out of your Mouth, as any Man's living; 'tis a place you never frequent.

sp.speaker: L. G.
sp.p: Don't be too poſitive; there are as many Intrigues begun, continu'd, and ended there as any where: Devotion has the leaſt ſhare in thoſe that come thither; they are all too much taken up with particular Saints, to join in the Prayers of the Congregation; unleſs it be when they pray for the deſolate and afflicted, among whom are rank'd all deſpairing Lovers, and ſuperanuated Virgins.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: And you dare venture upon a mad Reformer?

sp.speaker: L. F.
sp.p: Dare I embrace the greateſt bleſſing upon Earth; the only happineſs all my Deſires are levell'd at! I receive you, Madam, as my Preſerver, my guardian Angel, to whom I owe the greateſt comforts of Life, Virtue, and Reputation.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p:
You'll repent your forwardneſs in a little time: Now I have begun to wear
• he Breeches, it will be a hard task to make me lay 'em aſide again—

sp.speaker: L. F.
sp.p: That ſhan't ſave you; I have your Hand, and will keep it; 'tis not in your power to draw it back.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: We had better ſtay t'other Twelvemonth, and ſee how the World goes— Marriage is a tickliſh Calling; and tho' we have a good ſtock of Love to begin the World with, we may chance to break theſe hard times.

sp.speaker: L. F.
sp.p: It is but running the hazard.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: You are obſtinate; give me but half an Hour's time to ſerve my Siſter in an Affair depending, and I am for you; if you take a turn in the Gallery in the mean while, you will find ſomething to divert you; we will ſhow you the way.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: Not a ſtep farther—

sp.speaker: To.
sp.p: You won't diſappoint a Lady when ſhe ſends for you?

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: No, no, when ſhe ſends for me!

What a look there is? is that a Face to receive good News with? never did poor disbanded Officer wear a more rueful Phiz when he was petitioning for Arrears. Put on a better Countenance to entertain her, or, by Heav'n, I will leave you.

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: Phy, phy, Sir, your fullenneſs becomes you, juſt as gravity does a Mountebank.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.p: So, that is pretty tolerable— Then I tell thee once more, the Day is your own; your Miſtreſs is conſtant and kind, your Rival diſcarded, and you the Favourite Lover.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: You wou'd delude me; I know my Fate, and can ſit down contented with it.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: Sit down! do— let another be happy in your ſtead.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.p: With all my Heart, balk your Fortunes now I have made 'em for you; 'tis but my labour loſt.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: Are you in earneſt?

sp.speaker: To.
sp.p: If you won't believe me, believe your Senſes, believe my Lady; here is one can ſatisfie you better.

sp.speaker: L. G.
sp.p: No more ſtrangeneſs, I beſeech you; I beg your pardon for the diſquiets I have given you, and in recompence offer you all you wiſh for: Nay, no raptures, time is precious, you will find my Siſter in the next room, take your Friend with you— She will give you your Inſtructions.
You, Mr. Townley, muſt ſtay with me; and however I change my Diſcourſe, tune your Anſwers to it.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.p: When do you expect him?

sp.speaker: L. G.
sp.p: Immediately.
He is here already— You muſt not ſee him— 'tis in vain to excuſe it, I am well enough ſatisfy'd of his Conduct.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.p: Townley here! I don't like that—

sp.speaker: To.
sp.p: But Madam—

sp.speaker: L. G.
sp.p: Pray Sir deſiſt— I will hear nothing in his favour, who would make a Maygame of me— Am I a fit Subject for his pretended Paſſions— I will not be affronted ſo.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.p: He did not deſign you ſhould.

sp.speaker: L. G.
sp.p: Give me leave to truſt my own Ears— I heard him ſay all the pretenſions he made, were only for the name of an Intriegue, and to trifle away a few Hours.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.p: Nay then I acquieſce— I dare defend him no farther—

sp.speaker: L. G.
sp.p: I would not have you; he is now my Averſion of Averſions— The only Man I would ſhun and avoid— To ſhew you there is no dearth of Lovers— I have already made choice of another— A Man of Eſtate and Underſtanding— Who tho' he wants Mr. Truelove's youth, has ſincerity to recommend him to a Woman's liking—

sp.speaker: To.
sp.p: May I know the happy Man?

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.p: [Aſide] Now I fear.

sp.speaker: L. G.
sp.p: 'Tis his Friend Richley— Modeſty forbids me to tell him— yet I could wiſh he knew my ſentiments.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.p: And I too—

sp.speaker: L. G.
sp.p: How! turn'd Eve's dropper— Is that like a Gentleman, to know more of your Miſtreſſes mind than ſhe is willing you ſhould— I could find in my heart— yet ſince you have heard my confeſſion, it is but a folly to ſtand off longer— upon one condition I am yours—

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.p: Tranſporting Words— I would do any thing to purchaſe you; be it what it will, I am reſolv'd to agree to it.

sp.speaker: L. G.
sp.p: I'll but ſtep into the next Room, and you ſhall know your task.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.p: I little expected to ſee this Day, Frank, thou wert always ſuch an Enemy to the Clogs, of for better for worſe, that I ſhould as ſoon have expected Liberality in an Uſurer, as Love in thee—

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.p: 'Tis not in the fate of Man to avoid it— He that had told me a Week ſince I was ſo nigh Matrimony, had been to me as ridiculous as a Lecture of Sobriety to 〈◊〉 Drunkard— Now I recant my Errour, and am as you ſee juſt making a Settlement for Life—

div.stage: Enter Lady Gen. with Truelove diſguis'd like a Lawyer— and after them Eugenia and Lord Frollickſome.

sp.speaker: L. G.
sp.p: When my firſt Husband dy'd, I made a Vow never to be any Man's, that would not gratify my humour ſo far, as to ſet his Hand to whatever I brought him without peruſing the Contents— If you dare make the venture, you know the price— if not—

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.p: I beſeech you, Madam, don't ſuſpect me in ſuch a Trifle— I am only ſorry 'tis not ſomething of greater difficulty, that you might ſee I value nothing comparable to you—

sp.speaker: L. G.
sp.p: You ſay there can be no flaw found in it, Mr. Split-cauſe?

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: Give me leave to know my buſineſs, Madam— Upon the honeſt word of a Lawyer, there is no Hole for him to creep out at— 'Tis faſt and firm— the obligation to endure in Secula Seculorum, as we ſay— if he do's not ſatisfy it— are you ready, Sir— do you want any thing?—

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.p: Pen and Ink.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: I can furniſh you— I never go without my Inſtruments, a Lawyer with no Ink-horn is as ridiculous as a Souldier with no Weapons— How ſay you, he Sir—

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.p: Ev'n as you ſay— pray diſpatch [Writes] There Madam—

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: Francis Richley— a good Hand, truly— a very pretty Hand — were you never bred up to the Law, Sir— 'tis a crabbed Studdy— but Men of induſtry conquer it— The Witneſſes— Come, Sir, if you pleaſe, your hand—

sp.speaker: To.
sp.p: [Writes] There it is.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: John Townley— Now for my own [Writes] and there it is.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.p: How, Truelove! Where were my Eyes— then I find my diſgrace— I am Fool'd and Chous'd.

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: No— not Chous'd— that's a hard word to give a Lady; only plaid upon, or ſo—

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: Serv'd in your own kind, my dear Friend, or ſo—

sp.speaker: L. G.
sp.p: Pray forbear, Gentlemen— Mr. Snap, do your Office.

div.stage: Enter Squeezum diſguis'd like a Bailiff, four dancing Maſters like his Followers.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: I Arreſt you, Sir, at the ſuit of my Lady Generous, in an Action of 1000 l.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.p: Hah!

sp.speaker: To.
sp.p: Never vex, you are but going to make a Settlement for Life—

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: 'Tis for my intereſt to have you out of the way— they ſhall uſe you well—

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.p: Very well— I am betray'd— it will be my turn to do you the favour, Sir— there is ſuch a thing as a Debt of five hundred Pound—

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: Which you have here releas'd to me, beſides a Judgment given for 1000 l. more— How do you like the alteration?— Are you for new diſcoveries?— Your Head lies much towards Politicks— 'tis pity you are not a States-Man.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.p: There's no way to get looſe, but confeſſing my ſelf a Rogue [Aſide] Spare my guilt— I own my ſelf a Villain— the greateſt of Villains, a falſe Friend — Yet forgive me this one ſlip, my future honeſty ſhall make amends for it— I might plead the imperiouſneſs of Love for my crime, but I had rather take it upon my ſelf— To repair which, I confeſs the Deed— and before all this Company make Mr. Truelove my Heir, for I reſolve never to Marry—

sp.speaker: L. G.
sp.p: Can this be?

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.p: I am ready to ſeal it— if you dare not take my Word—

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: That I forbid, I muſt not be out-done in generoſity — I reſtore you the Judgment— Nay, take it— and with it my Friendſhip—

sp.speaker: L. G.
sp.p: Mine.

sp.speaker: Town.
sp.p: And mine.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: [Diſcovering himſelf] And if you pleaſe mine.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.p: Mr. Squeezum!

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: You muſt forgive what he did for my ſake.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.p: Forgive! Yes, and thank him too— thus thank him [Embrace] His honeſty has prevented a Crime in me— the remembrance of which muſt have eternally diſquieted me—

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: I knew your Nature, and made bold to do you this ſervice againſt your will— There are times when ſeeming Treachery is the trueſt Friendſhip— and to falſify a Man's truſt, the only way to be juſt to it.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.p: Experience confirms it— To prevent temptations of the like ſort for the future— Be Maſter of me and mine.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: Let your Neceſſities know me for their Friend—

sp.speaker: To.
sp.p: Me.

sp.speaker: L. G.
sp.p: And me— Come, Gentlemen, if you pleaſe now to do your Office, I ſuppoſe it won't be diſpleaſing —

div.stage: A Dance— Townley looking diſcontented all the while.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.p: Our thanks to your Ladyſhip.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: [Coming up to Townley] Why this ſadneſs, to damp the univerſal joy— You are not pleaſed with my good Fortune—

sp.speaker: To.
sp.p: Say rather diſpleas'd at my own bad— I have ſeen you ſetled in the free poſſeſſion of all your deſires— 'tis time now to mind my own affairs— [Going] Adieu—

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: You won't leave us ſo?

sp.speaker: To.
sp.p: Better leave you, than ſtay to ſpoil your Mirth— I am out of tune, and all with ev'ry thing elſe ſo.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: Your Ladyſhip muſt uſe your Authority here, or we ſhall loſe Mr. Townley, he • unning in queſt of he do's not know whom.

sp.speaker: L. G.
sp.p: He can't be ſuch a Mad-man?

sp.speaker: To.
sp.p: I muſt go— My Quiet, my Life, my All depends upon finding her, which • ill do, if diligence can do it.

sp.speaker: L. G.
sp.p: Are you ſure ſhe is worth finding— ſhe is ten to one ſome Town Jilt or •• dy Errant that has been long in purſuit of a Husband, and has at laſt ſingled you out.

A needy Beauty perhaps, who for want of Fortune is fain to lye upon the •
•• ch— You ſhan't fling your ſelf away.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p:
Think no more of her— The Siſter you have ſo often heard me ſpeak of ••
• n Town— if a good Face and 5000 l. will pleaſe you, ſhe is yours— ſpeak, •• it a Match?

sp.speaker: To.
sp.p: I would not have you miſconſtrue my refuſal, for Pride or Stupidity— but I 〈◊〉 reſolv'd to have her— and none but her— who if ſhe were here,

div.stage: Enter Sab. and claps him on the Back.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.p: As ſhe is here,

sp.speaker: To.
sp.p: Should be mine inſtantly— you would retreat— No Faith, Madam, you 〈◊〉 ſtand to it now— Here are two or three Couples going to the ſame ſport— 〈◊〉 won't ſpoil a Humour—

Not I— tho' you were ſo hard-hearted, as to give me a flat denial in the Park ••
• terday— D'you remember Sylvia?

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p:
So, Jack, we muſt be Brothers in ſpite of Fate— A Siſter of my giving won't •
•• ſe you, you muſt pick for your ſelf—

sp.speaker: To.
sp.p: To this face, where-ever I find it, I ſwear Allegiance. Come, Sir, you are ſlow, 〈◊〉 the way to Church.

div.stage: Enter No-wit running, his Crevat torn, and Perewig ruffled.

sp.speaker: No.
sp.p: Oh! ſave me, ſave me!

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: From what?

sp.speaker: No.
sp.p: That Legion of Devils, my Wife.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: What's the matter?

sp.speaker: No.
sp.p: My Shoulders, my Shoulders! She has been uſing the rod of Authority, 〈◊〉 beſtow'd plentiful Caſtigation upon 'em, the firſt day of our Marriage.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: How did you provoke her to it?

sp.speaker: No.
sp.p: Not at all, as I hope to be ſav'd— I provoke her— No ſuch ma • ter truly— I am not ſuffer'd nigh enough— By the pleaſures of generation, I 〈…〉 much as k • ſt her ſince we were Marry'd.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: There's her quarrel to you— ſtick cloſe to her, ſhe will ſoon be in a • etter humour.

sp.speaker: No.
sp.p:
I can't abide to ſtick cloſe to her, ſo I can't— ſhe do's ſo hug an •
〈…〉 Monkey, that it would make any Chriſtian aſham'd of her; ſhe nothing but 〈…〉 him, and all forſooth becauſe he is like a Man— ſure I may be thought as like one as he—

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: With a great deal of Juſtice— Phoo! you ſhould never mind thoſe 〈◊〉 Women will have their Play-fellows—

sp.speaker: No.
sp.p: What Monkeys 〈◊〉 Foh.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: Monkeys or Bea • s— there is not a Pin to chuſe between 〈…〉 come I'll ſee you reconcil'd, I'll mediate for you.

sp.speaker: No.
sp.p:
No need for that— I can go to ſiner Women, thoſe that won't uſe 〈…〉 One of 'em clap't my cheeks t'other day, and ſaid I had a good Country 〈…〉
••
tray'd my quality— hang me if ſhe did not proteſt any body might read 〈…〉 my Face.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: A common Strumpet— a mercenary Jade of the Town.

sp.speaker: No.
sp.p: Mercenary— O Law— and I'll ſwear then ſhe proffer'd me 〈…〉 for half a Crown— She was ſome Gentlewoman without doubt, ſhe had 〈…〉 Velvet-hood and Scarf on.

sp.speaker: Squ.
sp.p: Little do's he think that they are as true ſigns of a willing Tit as a 〈…〉 Well, well, forget her, I'le ſatisfy your Wife.

sp.speaker: No.
sp.p: Will you indeed now— but will you ſatisfy her— You were 〈…〉 Friend, that's the truth on't— but to undertake ſuch a task as ſatisfying a Wom •• is mighty kind— Dear Rogue come along— but be ſure you 〈…〉 nough.

sp.speaker: L. G.
sp.p:
Has not this coold you a little?— are not you afraid of facin •
〈…〉 Neighbours?

sp.speaker: To.
sp.p: Not a jot; for though

l.hi: The choice which int'reſt makes ſoon tedious grows,
And haſty Paſſions do themſelves deſtroy;
Yet when Deſert, that kindled, feeds the Flame,
Love is for ever freſh, and ſtill the ſame.
